moves.1... e5: standard opening. In this game, the development of the opening favors white, but black lays a trap
moves.2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bc4 Nh6 4. d4 f6 5. Bxh6 g: At this stage, the board favors white who looks poised to secure a famous victory
moves.8... h5 9. a3 Na6 10. b4 Bb7 11. Nh4: At this stage, white is about to make several mistakes that are costly in material and end up changing the board to favor black
moves.11... f5: this challenge offers a pawn to the knight or pawn and white chooses
moves.15. Na2 Qxd5: this. So from even to plus 5 points because of one mistake. The board looks a lot different now, and black will mount an attack from a stronger position.
moves.16. f3 c6: first I have to secure the king
moves.17... Qd4+ 18. Kh1: I like the king in the corner..I see a mate developing with my bishops help
moves.19. Rad1: My pawn at d-8 is vulnerable through and through though
moves.19... Kc7: so I better improvise a castle
moves.21. Qf6: This next decision is key. I opted to sacrifice my castle to lock the queen in the lower half of the board. I choose to do so because I am planing to bring out my bishop on f-8 to join in the mate
moves.21... Qxa3: soI capture the key pawn and increase my haul...while freeing up my bishop, sacrificing a castle, and keeping the queen on that side of the board away from my attack
moves.23... Nb8: now I get my bishop on b-7 involved but first I have to move my knight
moves.24. f6: White does not see the danger. so he pushes a pawn
moves.24... Ba6: the long reach of the bishop again
moves.25. Rd3: a castle for a bishop - of course I will thank you
moves.25... Bxd3 26. Rd1: this was a most interesting move. Why not capture the bishop?
moves.26... Be2: this is really a waste of time, because the bishop needs to move to c-5 a the queen to f-3 and its over.
moves.27. f7 Bxd1 28. Qg6: this was a funny move by white. I am not sure what the plan was
moves.28... Qxf3+: but this is the end game
